content.text: Yes the procedure is feasible, but the procedure described would not result in a 50 mL solution of NaCl with a concentration of 2.00 x-4M and a precision of less than 1%. This is due to an initial error in calculating the correct weight of solute needed for the reaction, "5.8440 gm."
Yes, it properly introduces the idea of error and the need for standard quantitative equipment in delivering a precise result.

The essay does use logical chronological organization and some transitional words in conducting a flow of ideas in this essay. However, at the overuse of the word "we" detracts from this logical flow of ideas.

Although the essay was mostly fine, it lacks some key components such as proper calculated values important to the experiment. It also has a weak construction that relies on the first person and detracts from its logical flow of ideas. Finally, there is a small typo in the beginning and it lacks an overall concluding summary sentence.
It describes everything.
I would do the same exact procedure.
Good flow.
All it needed was a conclusion with a summary.

No specific procedures were described, and no measurement of the mass of reagent is listed. This reads more like a general description of how to perform the experiment. It does not include any calculations to prove that a 2.00*^-4 M solution with an inherent error of 1% can be produced.
The procedure does include the use of volumentric equipment, such as the pipet and flasks.
Transition words are present at the start of each sentence to connect the logic of the current sentence to that of the previous.

The essay needs a more specific procedure and needs to answer the prompt. The lack of both calculations and unstated measurements does not convince readers that the desired concentration can be achieved. Work must be shown for the concluding statement to prove your procedure works; otherwise, the reader can only assume the conclusion and results were made up.
The procedure does not outline a beginning value for NaCl. While it does pay attention to steps in the dilution procedures, it fails to account for error in the equipment.
While it does outline the process I can't help but feel as if the author is missing something else, possibly calculations.
The tone is straight forward, with no attention to keeping a logical flow of ideas present throughout the work.

While the author maintained a detailed process of dilution procedure, they failed to address other questions the prompt had asked for. Furthermore, the author did not provide initial values, nor was there any mention of NaCl.

First, the person used a dye to mix his or her solution, so it didn't even use the correct solute. However, this person has the right idea of diluting the solutions 3 times to achieve an inherent error of less than 1%.
The person clearly states to use 5 mL volumetric pipets, 50 mL flasks, etc.
The transition is very choppy. The person used numbers instead of words to label the procedures so there was no flow in the text.
The essay did not have good transitions. The topic sentence has some gramatical errors as well.
The serial dillution procedure is clearly defined in the essay. The use of pipettes, volumetric flask and the analytical balance will provide an error rate of less than 1%.

The essay clearly states that standard quantitative equipment in explaining the use of the volumetric flas, analytical balance and pipette. The use of serial dillution is the standard procedure for creating a dillute solution like this one.
Using the phrases, "After first dilution", and "As a result" allow the reader to follow along with the process of creating the dilute solution.
This procedure is defined very clearly and concisely, with few errors. The calculation of error in this procedure is clearly defined, and the result is a solution with less than 1% error.
Student was able to accurately state which equpiment is needed and the amount. It is detailed and to an exact amount, al in which is important to know when doing this dilution.

Student explains exactly which equipment is needed to perform this experiment. The calculations are also laid of for percent error being less than 1%. The following necessary equations are also stated for further assistance in this experiement.

student provided formulas such as M1V1=M2V2 to help asisst with calculations for this experiement. No transition words were found in this paragraph. Doesn't seem to be that big of a problem since I am still able to understand the directions.
Student is able to summarize the information and procedures which all concludes to a .9% inherent error. Student also made viable calculations upfront to back up information and procedures.

This procedure cannot be used to get the desired concentration because the author has made a mistake in the stoichiometric calculations in the first step. The calculated concentration of the first solution after dissolving the NaCl in distilled water is not 1.00x^-2M, it is 0.2M NaCl. This initial mistake leads to a wrong final concentration, as after the author's steps, the final concentration will be 4x^-3M and not their calculated value of 2x^-4M.

The essay uses the assigned equipment of the volumetric pipette, volumetric flask and the weighing balance, which are the standard quantitative equipment. The serial dilution process is the standard quantitative procedure for acquiring the dilute solution of 2.00x^-4M so the essay satisfies the requirement of using the right procedure and right equipment. However, the author does not acquire the desired concentration of the solution.

The essay has an easy-to-follow pace with concise wording and reasons for why each step is being carried out. The formulas and calculations are clearly described to show the logic behind the steps carried out. However, the calculations are wrong, so despite the good flow of words, the essay is ultimately misleading.

This text is well written and concise, but it contains wrong information and will eventually lead to the wrong concentration of NaCl being acquired, so it gets points for being well written but loses points for being inaccurate.

the person accurately mentioned about the goal of an experiment. The aim is to prepare 0.0002M of NaCl with less than 1% inherent error. However, writer forgets to mention about its volume which is 50ml. Nevertheless, writer still did good jobs in writing down the accurate usage of the equipments to prepare solution.

the writer put certain concern about reversing the steps to get the final concentration while maintaining the inherent error less than 1%. Writer did not mention about the number of dilutions in the experiments but he did mention about the final % of inherent error and also talk about the amount of mass he/she liked to begin with. Last but not least writer briefly mention about how he/she prepare the solution with equipment.

The Writer shows little significance error in terms of grammar or punctuation. However, I believe that the order of the writing can be better which the writer can firstly mention about how he/she gonna maintain the inherent error with given mass while describe this with procedure. Writer can also have conclusion sentence at the end to summarize the problem.

The overall logic of the essay is present and I believe that it should be in the higher range of score. However, writer can effectively improve the essay with improving certain criteria like writing down conclusive sentences or describe the procedure with reason behind in using such equipment.

The first sentence introduce the creation of a solution with a specific concentration. the procedure uses the equipment available to create a 50 mL solution with a concentration of 2.00 x-4M and erroe of 1% of less.
The procedure uses 3 solutions to dilute the solution to the desired contration with inherent error of less than 1% using a 50.00 mL flask, 5 mL pipet and MettlerAE160 to mearure materials.

A few commas can be added to the essay. There appear to be no other errors grammatically or in spelling. Some sentences could be reformatted to increase clarity in the essay, but the essay does not lack clarity as written.

The concluding sentences bring the procedure to a finish. Points were lost not specifying what MattlerAE160 is, not specifically telling the reader the amount of sodium chloride used in the procedure, and the use of firdt person directions. The first person makes the procedure more like a diary entry than a specific procedre instructing the reader.
The error is brielfy mentioned, but the procedure checks out. Also, the author noted the importance of calculating ahead of time to achiee a target molarity

Although the specific balance used to measure mass is listed, the rest of the equipment feels like an afterthought. The individual inherent errors for this equipment are not mentioned, and as such, a reader might attempt this using equipment of varying error
Mostly prepositional phrases, but the procedure uses proper transitions
Missing some specifics as to the procedure and equipment used, but the essay reads well
Only 5-mL volumetric pipets and 50-mL volumetric flasks can be used. However, 1-mL pipet and 0-mL flask are used in this method.
Again, the 1-mL pipet and the 0-mL flask are not allowed to be used.
The author used "First", "Since" and other transition words.
In this procedure, equipment that are not included in the requirement are used and therefore it leads to the big mistake on designing the procedure.

This person clearly did not read and completely understand the materials list available.  There was no mention of being able to use a 1.00mL volumetric pipet in the Source Materials section of this assignment.  From this assumption onwards, this whole procedure is impossible since for dilutions, solutions are created from the net product of the previous solution(s).  If anything goes wrong or is wrongly assumed in the beginning, the error will compound and eventually lead to a completely wrong end result.

This procedure does mention using specific pieces of standard quantative equipment, but neglects the fact that a 1.00mL pipet was never provided.  Additionally, the fact that the person uses standard quantative processes to make the solution is a plus, but the fact that the 1.00mL pipet is assumed to be had subtracts from the validity of the person's credibilty and accuracy.

The usage of transition words such as first, then, finally during the procedure and the use of next, then, etc. help the overall flow of the paragraph in having good flow and coherence as a whole.  Goob job.

Because of the incorrect assumption that a 1.00mL pipet can be used, the person had done the whole procedure incorrectly.  Due to this error, I believe that a score of no higher than 7 can be given to the person although the calculations have been done correctly in addition to formatting and conveying the idea.  Misreading information should be an error that is not made at this level of education.

Although the essay contains a procedure which results in the creation of a 2.00*^-4 M NaCl solution, it does not provide any explanation or calculation of the inherent error. Also, the use of required standard quantitative equipment, including 5.00 mL volumetric pipet and 50 mL volumetric flask, is not evident within the experiment; instead, the essay includes equipment not required in the criteria.

The suggested procedure within this essay uses equipment that are not available. The required standard quantitative equipment was 5.00 mL volumetric pipet and 50 mL volumetric flask, both of which not mentioned within the essay. Instead, the essay describes an experiment using a 1.00 mL volumetric pipet and a 0 mL volumetric flask.

The essay includes the use of chronologic transition words such as "first," "then," and "finally," all of which allow an easier understanding of the procedure in the experiment. Also the use of transition words give the essay a greatquality in portraying an understandable flow of ideas.

Although the essay includes a great flow of ideas and a procedure in creating a 2.00*^-4 M NaCl aqueous solution, it does not do so by following the criteria. The use of equipment not available for the experiment, the inability to calculate the inherent error within the experiment, and the process of just one dilution undermine the writer's understanding of this experiment. However, the essay demonstrates a an organized flow throughout an experiment.

[1st solution]=0.5884/(22.99+35.45)/0.05000=0.200M[2nd solution]=0.200x0.00500/0.05000=0.0200M[3rd solution]=0.0200x0.005/0.05000=0.00200M[4th solution]=0.00200x0.005/0.0500=0.000200M=2.00x^(-4)MTherefore 50ml of NaCl solution with required concentration is achieved by this procedure. %error of final solution=(0.0002/0.5844 + 0.04/50.00 + 3(0.01/5.00 + 0.04/50.00)) x 0=0.954%Therefore precision is accurately calculated and less than required precision of 1%.

This procedure uses a digital balance, volumetric flasks and volumetric pipets to make quantitative measurements. Therefore this essay does indeed describe a serial dilution that appropriately uses standard quantitative equipment whenever possible or necessary.
The author appropriately used these transition phrases: "To begin,...", "After...", "Next,...", "Again,...", and "Repeat...". This contributes to the essay's coherent and logical flow of ideas.

This essay does well to describe a procedure that uses appropriate equipment to produce the required solution to the required precision, but the minimum mass of solid NaCl is not used. Since the main objective of the essay is achieved, this essay is off to a great start.However, the quality of language could be better. The first sentence is unnecessarily long, and does not introduce the topic succinctly.  There is also a grammatical error; namely "After sufficiently swirling". Another issue is that which is referred to as the "first dilution", is actually not a dilution but rather a primary standard or stock solution. These are the main issues that lost the essay some marks. That said, the essay did present a reasonably logical and coherent flow of ideas, and so the quality of language was by no means poor.
Yes the error is below 1% however they could have used even less starting NaCl and performed one less dilution. This would further minimize error.
Author mentions equiment used and a feasible procedure to obtain a final solution of the given concentration.
I found myself lost in the wording of the sentences. Needs to be more concise.
Could have used less NaCl. Mechanical errors. No concluding sentence.
The essay does have a topic sentence and got a solution that has a precision of 1 %.
The procedure used a serial dilution that has an inherent error less than 1%. The procedure uses more than 0.0584g which is not good.
The essay doen't have mechanical errors and uses transition words such as "next","agiain".
The essay shows that the author has a clear understanding of the concepts and procedures. However the design is not the best one and it wastes NaCl.

The procedure that was outlined will result in a 2.00x-4M solution. Weighing out 58.5mg of NaCl and diluting it in 0mL of water will result in a 0.02M solution. The first dilution of 5mL into 0mL of water will give a 0.002M solution and the final dilution will give a solution that has a concentration of 2.0x-4M. The sums of the errors for the equipment are as follows in the order in which they were used: (0.1mg/58.5mg + 0.04mL/50mL + 0.01mL/5mL + 0.04mL/50mL + 0.01mL/5mL + 0.04mL/50mL). The inherent error for this procedure is also less than 1% given that the sum of all the uncertainties for the equipment results in an error of 0.81%.

The essay explains the reasoning behind the dilutions and outlines a procedure that uses quantitative equipment. The dilution procedure could have been described more eloquently such as by avoiding saying "5mL of this solution taken, disposed in an empty flask" and instead describing a quantitative transfer of solution.
The writer uses transition phrases such as "to start," " also", "knowing that", "given this result" to make the essay flow nicely.

The writer does a good job explaining the logic of the dilutions and explains the calculations that lead to a solution of concentration 2.00x-4M. They include an introductory sentence, transition phrases, reason for the procedure, a description of the use of equipment, and a concluding sentence. Still, I think they could elaborate more on the procedure and describe it more quantitatively.
The calculations work out.
volumetric equipement was mentioned in the beginning, then the values were iterated throughout the rest of the essay.
Phrases such as "given this result", "With that...", "Also", etc.

The text focuses on the derivation of the procedures that will be followed to prepare the solution. The information is overall correct and solid. This essay didn't recieve a full  because the wording of the essay is a little confusing at times.

Yes, all of the equiptment is availilbe in lab and the calculations are correct. But they don't really describe a procedure as much as a calculation. I would just write out what needs to be done.  Calculations for Concectration is Correct:.0584g x (1/58.44) mol/g = 9.99x-4mol9.99x-4mol / .050 L = .01998MM1V1 = M2V2 -> M2 = M1V1/V2(.01998M)(5mL)/ (50mL) = .001998 MM3 = M2V2/V3(.001998 M)(5mL)/ (50mL) = 1.998 x-4 M ~ 2.0 x-4 M. Calcultion for Error is Correct:Inherent Error is the Sum from all equiptment used:Scale .0002/ .0584 x 0% = .345%(3x) 50 mL Volumetric flask 3( .04/50 x 0%)= 3(.08%) = .24%(2x) 5 mL Volumentric pipet 2( .01/5 x 0%) = 2(.20%) = .40%Total Inherent Error: .985%
I know you mean to use volumetric equiptment, but you don't ever say "volumentric." You do use serial dillutions though, which is good.
To start,... Also,... Using the same equasion, ...
Doesn't exactly describe a procedure, mostly a calculation. The science works, but make sure to just talk about the topic of the essay: a procedure using serial dillutions.

The dilutions, as stated, reduce the molarity by a factor of 0.1 so with a starting molarity of .2M, after 3 serial dilutions, the molarity is 2 x-4.  The initial measurement would provide a .0342% error in addition to the .08% error of the flask. This gives .1142% error. Each dilution gives an error of .28%. Three dilutions therefore give .84% error. Adding the two, we have .95% error as stated.
The essay mentions the use of volumetric flask and pipet.
The procedure of dilutions is simple and the author uses "then" to transition between steps.
The essay was straight forward, but did not introduce the topic well or summarize well. The approach to creating the solution was not the most efficient.
The equipment is all used properly and the inherent error was calculated correctly.
Both the 50 ml flask and the 5 ml pipet were referenced and explained how they would be used.
The flow is very logical.  However, the first few introductory sentences seem fragmented and/or repititious.
The essay is very well written and addresses the prompt fully.

Although the procedure given leads to a 2.00x^-4M solution of NaCl if done in the amounts of reagents listed, the process isn't totally feasible given the equipment available. A 5-mL pipet cannot accurately measure 1.17mL of a solution. Likewise, the equipement available cannot accurately measure 48.83mL of distilled water either.
The procedures list the volumetric equipements to use at each step.
There are adverbial and adjectival phrases at the beginning of sentences to help with transitions ("using this value", "To do this", etc.).

Since the numerical calculations of the serial dilution works out in giving us a 2.0x^-4M solution, points are given in that regard. Nevertheless, the writer suggested the 5mL pipet and 50mL volumetric flask to measure out volumes that wouldn't be possible with that equipement. Even if other equipment is used, the inherent precision will need to be recalculated. Beyond the technical bits, this essay has some grammatical errors as well.

The procedure suggest takinga 1.17ml aliquot of primary solution with a 5ml pipet which is not feasible. Also, the error of the experiment is, if taking 1.17ml with a 5ml were even possible, in truth over 1%: [(.0002g/.0250g) + 2(.04ml/50ml) + (.01ml/1.17ml)] 0%= 1.81%.
Though some of the measurements the procedure suggest is not possible, it does not refer to the use of quantitative equipemtn or procedures.
The essay makes use of prepositional phrases and transitions to create a flow within the essay.

In the attempt to satisfy one of the requirements, using a small amount of reagent, the author of the text makes several mistakes such as: calculations with error and measuring 1.17ml aliquot with a 5ml pipet. These mistakes display a vague understanding of the prompt.
Yes the error is less than 1%.
The text refers to the volumetric flasks as just "flasks".
The essay contains transition words so it is coherent.
The text could be more specific with what equipment was used and did not use enough sodium chloride in the beginning.
The dilutions are correctly carried out.
The student chooses volumetric flasks and pipets accordingly.
The student clearly labels the steps in the process.
The only mistake seems to be that the student explains the method of finding the margin of error quite vaguely.
His calculation is right. But he forgot the inherent error of the Mettler AE160 balance, which is +-0.2mg, and will cause 0.34% inherent error. Whatever, this will not influence too much.
He/she used 50-ml volumetric flask and 5-ml volumetric pipet, and also Mettler AE160 balence, which are all standard equipment.
The logic is apparently.
Missed the topic sentense and summary sentense    -1Used too much NaCl, unnecessary   -2

The suggested procedure use digital balance to weigh 0.5844g NaCl and use 5 ml volumetric pipet and 50 ml volumetric flask to dilute twice in order to get the desired solution. The result solution is 2.00x^(-4)M with an error of 0.95 % which is demonstrated in the text.

The required equipment for the procedure suggested by the text includes digital balance, 50ml volumetric flask, and 5ml volumetric pipette.  All of them are standard quantitative equipment available in the lab.
The procedure use very clear indicator words like "first", "next", "fifth". It is very easy for reader to follow the writer's idea in this text.

The procedure suggested in the text includes the very detailed correct steps for serials dilution and verify the inherent error of the dilution falls in the accepted range. However, it requires more than 0.0584 g of NaCl which is more than necessary amount of reagent to achieve the necessary precision. And there is neither introduction sentence at the beginning, nor summary sentence at the end of the text. It is notclear for the reader to understand the procedure.
Student thoroughly calculated data to achieve said precision.
Student makes mention of equipments that satisfy this requirement.
Student goes straight into material without use of transition words or phrases, leading the response to lack flow.
Student is missing integral parts.
The author relies on the reader to conclude certain things, mostly in not specifying the type of equipment used, but once this is accomplished, the dilution steps achieve the desired result.

While the errors in the equipment are listed, specifics are left out. Again, this is where the reader has to come to the conclusion that they should be using only equipment that matches the exact errors listed in the essay.
Each sentence begins as its own idea, with the exception of a "next" at the start of one of the sentences
The procedure is solid, the errors are included in the measurements, but it is missing some key "Essay" elements.
The text clearly mentions how the writer got the the amounts required in teh procedure. It did this by using the formula of (m2/m1) = (v1/v2).

It does mention that 5ml of solution from the past solutions are pipetted into the new solution/flask. However, it failed to mentiont that one needs to fill up the 50ml flask with dilute water in order to find  have a dilution of 2*^-4 at the end of the porcedure.
Transition words such as : to start off ... , the purpose of, before and Lastly made the text clearer and easier to follow.

The main issue with this text is that the procedures could be clearer and how the writer calculated 0.971% inherent error could be better. However, as a whole i really liked how the writer made the text into paragraphs so that the reader can follow the text easier.

This procedure initially suggests that a ml volumetric flask will be used, but I believe this is an unfortunate early typo.[1st solution]=0.584/(22.99+35.45)/0.05000=0.200M[2nd solution]=0.200x0.00500/0.05000=0.0200M[3rd solution]=0.0200x0.005/0.05000=0.00200M[4th solution]=0.00200x0.005/0.0500=0.000200=2.00x^(-4)MTherefore 50ml of NaCl solution with required concentration is achieved by this procedure.

This procedure mentions using a digital balance, pipets and volumetric flasks to make quantitative measurements. Therefore this essay does indeed describe a serial dilution that appropriately uses standard quantitative equipment; however, this procedure does not specify that volumetric pipets should be used.

The author appropriately used many transition phrases: "Before...", "To start...", "and upon...", "After...", "However,...", "Lastly,...", and "and so after...". This contributes to the essay's coherent and logical flow of ideas.

This essay does alright to describe a procedure that uses appropriate equipment (disregarding the typo in the initial paragraph) to produce the required NaCl solution to the required precision, but a minimum mass of NaCl was not used. Since the main objective was achieved, this essay is off to a decent start.Whilst there were some minor language errors, such as the mis-spelling of see as "se", the language was on the whole good. With many appropriate transitions, this essay presents a cohesive and logical flow of ideas that explain the principles behind the proposed dilution scheme very well.The main issue with this procedure is the severe lack of specific experimental guidance. The author fails to how to weigh the sample, how to quantitatively transfer the dye and aliquots of solutions into volumetric flasks. This essay assumes a large amount of information as common knowledge.
A large assumption is made that the weight of the sample is exactly .5844g, but otherwise, it is a standard serial dilution procedure with an error within the allotted range.
The author states familiarity with certain machines, such as the Mettler AE160, in order to lead the reader into following exactly the same procedure and achieving the exact same results.
First, then, finally...

Logically and gramatically, the essay is complete. I feel as if the author could have stated some things differently ("familiarity" with machines) and structured the essay better to include a proper conclusion. However, the serial dilution steps are correct and the error is well below the mark.

The procedure used is that of serial dilution and it will result in a 50ml solution of NaCl with a concentration of 2x^-4M with an error of less than 1%. This is possible because the author is using the assigned equipment and the number of serial dilutions will lead to the desired concentration being attained.

The essay uses the assigned equipment of the volumetric pipette, volumetric flask and the weighing balance, which are the standard quantitative equipment. The serial dilution process is the standard quantitative procedure for acquiring the dilute solution of 2.00x^-4M so the essay satisfies the requirement of using the right procedure and right equipment.

The essay has a lot of unnecessary repetition in terms of the way the different diluted solutions are described and in terms of the way the procedure is carried out. In addition, the uncertainties/errors of the different pieces of equipment are not stated and the calculation for how the total error was calculated is not shown either, so we have to take the author's word without any proof that the error is what they say it is. The reasoning for some of the steps carried out also does not seem satisfactory, e.g., the reason for which the volumetric pipette and volumetric flask were chosen to perform the experiment.

Although this essay describes the procedure accurately, it is missing some key elements such as the calculation of the total inherent error and the individual errors of the equipment used in the experiment. Also, this essay has too much repetition and could be structured in a more concise manner so as to avoid repetition.
After three serial dilutions the final solution is of the required concentration within .9542%.
Yes, the essay describes the use of volumetric flasks, volumetric pipets, and the Mettler AE160 scale.
The essay flows well and is easy to follow. The procedure is easy to understand and straight forward.
The essay is well written and the procedure was well thought out. However, the procedure was not the most efficient possible. That being said, the solution was within the required specifications.

the first sentence introduces the topic and goal of the procedure described throughout the essay. The procedure in the essay calls for the use of a balance, 5.00mL pipet, small beakers and a 50.00 mL volumetric flask.

The procedure described in this essay uses serial dilution and 5.754 g. of sodium chloride to create a 50. mL solution with concentraion 2.00 x-4M. The essay uses a balance, 5.00 mL pipet, small beakers, and 50.00 volumetrice flask to measure amounts of water and sodium chloride to create the solution.

There are grammatical and spelling errors in the essay. Analyzed is spelled analysed in the essay. Commas and spaces are missing throughout the essay. Milliliters is abreviated ml instead of mL throughout the essay.The only transition word and phrase used throughout the essay is then. It is used as a compound sentence conjunction instead of as a transition between procedure steps.

The final sentence of the essay is a statment of fact, not a concluding sentence. The final sentence leaves me with questions and uncertain of the procedure's completion.The numerous errors and unclear ideas earn a 6 from me. The procedure is confusing and unclear at some points.

[1st solution]=5.754/(22.99+35.45)/0.05000=1.969M[2nd solution]=1.969x0.00500/0.05000=0.1969M[3rd solution]=0.1969x0.005/0.05000=0.01969M[4th solution]=0.01969x0.005/0.0500=0.001969=1.969x^(-3)MTherefore 50ml of NaCl solution with required concentration is not achieved by this procedure. %error of final solution=(0.0002/5.754 + 0.04/50.00 + 3(0.01/5.00 + 0.04/50.00)) x 0=0.923Although the precision is less than 1%, the author did not accurately calculate the error of the final solution. On top of this, the final solution is not of the required concentration.

This procedure uses a digital balance, volumetric flasks and volumetric pipets to make quantitative measurements. Therefore this essay does indeed describe a serial dilution that appropriately uses standard quantitative equipment whenever possible or necessary.

This essay uses some, but not enough, transition phrases: "then transfer...", "They would then...", "The experimenter would again mix...", and "This process would be repeated...". These do a little to contribute to the essay's coherent and logical flow of ideas, but some transitional phrases are grammatically poor; namely "The experimenter would again mix..." and "This process would be repeated".

The major flaw in this procedure is the failure to produce NaCl solution of the required concentration. Although, the final solution's precision is under 1%, the author actually miscalculated it to be 0.0%.There are many grammatical errors in this essay. The author systemmatically fails to place a space after periods; this happens three times: "...solution.They would...", "...beaker.This process...", and "...step.The error".There are also many redundant phrases, such as "it was determined" and the comment on cleanup of material for efficiency and others. The essay would benefit most from a more coherent flow of ideas, perhaps by using more transitional phrases.

Although the procedures are a little confusing at first, the essay basically starts with 5.754g of NaCl and says that 4 serial dilutions are enough to get it down to a concentration of about 2.0x^-4M. The precision is also less than 1%. The only part which causes this procedure to be inaccurate is the initial mass of NaCl. 5.754g of starting NaCl will not give you 2.00x^-4M of solution with a precision less than 1%. This could be a typo, but these numbers are important when it comes to writing scientific papers.
The essay mentioned the use of the 50mL flash and the 5mL pipet.
Words such as "From preliminary calculations", "then", "In the proposed pathway", etc.

Although this pathway can work with the correct mass of starting material, this pathway is not the most optimal pathway. Beakers were not mentioned as equipement that can be used, but their role in these procedures are irrelevant. Some of the procedure is also confusing and not clearly worded.

This procedure, from the numbers provided in the last paragraph of the calibration,"an analytical balance which has inherent error of +.0005 to measure out the mass of solute (.000584g NaCl) and dissolve it into 50ml of water (measured out using a 50.00ml volumetric flask which has inherent error of +.01)"will result in an error that is appromately 85.63% since error is (0.0005/.000584 + 0.01/50.00)*0 = 85.64%.
It seems that only an analytical balance, and a 50mL volumetric flas is used, so it is well within the confines of the resoruces allotted for this procedure.

The author does a good job of starting out by explaining the necessary goals of this dilution and the calculations.  The flow of the procedure is forward leading, resulting in the materials and measurements necessary and a supposedly end point that gives the "right" (really wrong in actuality) answer.

Since the whole procedure and the process was incorrect, and the author did their calculations/ assumptions completely wrong, I do not think they deserve anything more than a score of five.  Without a proper concluding sentance and semi-use of transition phrases, it deserves a score of roughly a three.

This would produce the desired concentration and uses equipment available but the percision would be questionable using such a small sample of salt.
It makes some description of a procedure, but it is very confusing and hard to follow.
